WE, the trustees Of st. Peters Church in the
Borough OF Wilmington, State OF Delaware, see
ng an appeal to the public by william Larkin,
wherein he charges us, Peter Pierce, Bernard
M'Cann, Bernard MGuigen, and John Durnin,
with unlusty assailing, and most wantonIy SLAM
dering, the said Vim. Larkin's character. He
then proceeds to say he feels it duty he owes
to himself and his friends to rcpel the unauthor-
ICED, base and untonuded charges made by those
calumniators, and expose them to that contempt
they merit. He then comes forward, honest
man like, to exhibit to public view a statement of
the facts connected with the lottery case alluded
to: he requests the public to recolect the pc
riod the Legislature granted the lottery, in 1922,
for raising the sum Of 5000 dollars for the use of
st Peters Church and payment Of debts, over all
expenses; he then states the managers of the
lottery then agreed that one Of them should sign
the tickets, and receive the money, and pay
the pri2es-this was the most Substantial part of
the business, although poor Billy says il was un-
ortunate for him, or, the self-created trustees
would have it, it was unfortunate for the Church
the trustees are a set OF impndent fellows, for
not plying poor Billy's severe loss, and not the
losses of the church; poor Billy goes on to in
form the public he sold the lottery to Thomas
Hope, who commenced to sell the Tickets; and
after the sale of the first and second classes, hon
est Biy tells the public, with the most bare





and note, and payment oidcbts, the full amount
and upwards, say 1905 dollars Ashe treats the
pubIc opinion with the same nsoIence as he has
treated the congregation of St Peters Church,
we now challenge you to come before any three
or more respectable men of the Borough, and we
arc ready to meet any hour you appoint, face to
face, and if YOU can produce one solitary docu-
ment of receipt or settlement for any sum o.
money, even for one dollar, since the commence
ment of the drawing of the lottery until thi
day, we shall acknowledge your assertion to be
true, and ifyeM cannot produce any receipt o
settlement from the trustees of ST. Peter
Church you must be the most abandoned crea
ture upon carth--we challenge you to produce i
in forty-eight hours, or you stand convicted, a
YOU are; so that we shall prevent you from
imposing any longer on the public. Our for
bearance for so long time with you, was from
motives of charity, not wishing to iniure you
character, as we would do, for any man in busi
ness; but you are the same obdurat'
and perverted wretch STILL after all our indul
pence to you. We point out an infamous false
hood on the face of the document you have Sc
before the public, where you say you sold 81.
classes of the lottery to Thomas Hope for 50
dollars each, to be paid by Hope as each clas
was Sold You state that after the lst and Cd class
es were sold, you paid the church the sum Q
1906 dollars in cash and note. You could not pa
uns Of ope thousand dollars, which you state yo
TO TILE PUBLIC.

Mr., Billy Laikn why are YOU barking at nc
We never had the change Of an unpleasant word.
+! know Of no cause Of your slan,lerously abusing
me, excepting my refusing you to put my shoul
der, as YOU termed it, to shove yoUr improper
paper, which you called your accompt current,
without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
uftruth. IshoNed it TO Mr. Wales, who is one
of the four law agents employed against you.--
Do you state there is no suit against YOU but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. Mr. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intrudcd yourself in
Ia my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr.. keenan, SAY he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that MIR. keenan, is parish priest in Lancaster;
and that he told you never lived in Lancaster,
so sec that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink. You forget when
you committed your ialsehoods and deiamations
to be published, that your attack on me must
! be founded ON envy and falsehood; as the public
know that ! advertise in this Borough in two
newspapers to let every one in the United
States know who | am, what | am, and where
am, so that YOU are, to make the most of YOU
bad minded man. The principle cause, be
| cyc, of your behaviour, is my sending you bach
pound of spermaceti candles, which wanted
quarter of pound Of the weight. done SO t.
prevent your doing 50 again-you, in an nsolen
manner, told the woman that your weights were
as honest as mine. But this would not do, you
son had to give hera pound of candles, as sh
paid YOU for them This is one ofthe causes G
your savage lying, and vindictiye malice.

THE Subscriber takes this opportunity to in
form the public, that the establishment hereto
fore conducted by James Ray, Esq, together
with the accounts connected with the business
of that establishment from the first of January,
1926, have passed into his hands; and that he
will continue the business in all It's branches, at
the Old Stand, corner of Tatnall and Queen-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House, where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,
Mould and Dipt CANDLES, Fuiier's, Feilow and
Brolun soar, of the best quality.

Litter is very essential to cattle, when let
into yards, without which yard manure is q
small account, and unless it be in fuH flro-
portion to the cattle in the yard, it is not
thought highly of; but is as half done thing.
Good farmers in England. deem FIJI litter
ing of cattle, when in yards, of such impor-
tance that after reaping with sickes and in
ming their wheat, they cut The stubbl- and
stack it for litter. Besides straw and stub
BILE for litter, they apply to the same use,
fern (brakes) and such other vegetable sub
stances as they can procure; and they buy
straw from common farmers who are not in
the practice of littering. In all countries.
common farmers are indifferent to improve
ments they look not beyond cid habits. and
it is prudent that they venture not on eXten-
sive new projects, without first making ex-
pertinent A full littering is three loads OF
10 or 13,0oolbs. OF straw to each grown
beast.


1t would be more economical however,
to cut the straw with a straw cutter, even
when It is intended for litter. But if cut and
mixed, OF given with other food or roots it
affords wholesome provender for cattle.
The best way, therefore, is to litter your cat
tie with brakes, stubbies, leaves and other
vegetable substances of less value than
straw, and cut and distribute yonr straw for
fodder. Ifpossible feed your cattle under
cover, and provide them at least a shed to
lodge under, and they will require not only
less litter but less food than if fed and lodg,
ed in an open yard. "Many farmers" says
the Domestic Encyclopedia, feed in their
yards in racks, and suppose they gain every
possible advantage from the practice. by the
saving of dung dropped, trampled and wa
tered by the cattle; and though this practice
is certainly preferable to wastetul pasturns
or to feeding in rack Cor from stacks i'll the
fields, vet it ought to be recolleeted that the
manure will be much inferior to that made
and preserved under cover. For there are OBJ
jections against the practice Of yard feeding,
viz: Danger from a vicious beast injurins
another, the irritation arising from then
contentious for food and worrying BY flies,
all of which are avoided BY feeding in stalls
under cover"

dropsey, viz Put an ounce of the inner bark
of elder into china basin, add gill of
boiling water, and few whole caraway
seeds-Let it stand eighteen hours, and
then squeeze out the liquor. 1t is brisk
cathartic and diui etic.

From experiments made by Sir James
Hall. it has been found that the leaves Of
the grapevine. dried in the shade, make an
excellent and extremely wholesome tea,
though differing in taste and favour from
that commonly used. Besides also being ad
mirably calculated for making Vinegar, the
prunings of the vine, on being bruised and
put into vat or mashng tub, and boiling
water poured over them, in the same way
as is done with malt, will produce liquor OF
a fine vinous quality, which being fer
mented, forms substitute for beer; and
which, on being distilled produces good
spirit Of the nature of brandy.

would further remark, that the second,

81 shall state, one OF the four managers O.

shop, where you began your old trade Of tlack.
guarlng us. You know YOU promised t'iat
day, which was the Esd Of January last, 70 bring
up your books and appointed the Doctor 10 set
Tie with the church on your part, aud We al1-
pointed the late ana rcyercd Victor Du Pont on
our part; which you agreed to: after, We saw
Nlr Du punt he said il sou would carry up yodl
\ books to Doctor Purcell 10 he examined, and If
the doctor could do any thing With the b0oks re-
specting settlement lr Du Pont would call on
the Doctor SATURDAY atter,t consult with him,
if they could arrange d settlement We return
ed to William Larkn and informed him Of what
Mr. Du Pont said to us-Ai Wkin's answer to us
was, he had no books and would settle no ac-
counts. See this unpilncipled man-eqnally re
gardless ofhis solemn promise, or Of committing
sacrllcge. Ills actions are the surest standard
to judge him by. After the Lottery was drawn
in January, 1924, we, the trustees Of St Peters
!, Church, insisted on settlement from Larkin,-
What does this monster Of finiqu:ty do TO ann
hilate the church and trustees, that, as he
supposed there would be none 10 demand the
proceeds ofthe Lottery of him,-Iic causes VII
lam Boyd sue the Church for the amount of his
bill, which was about $1,000, with AN Npcct.;ion
OF MIR Bord's getting Judgment and execution
and then selling the house He did nnt wish ia
be bothered for cttery money--hc had better
use for il than giving il to -. Peter or st. Paul.
BY his Withholding from the Church the plucced,
OF the LOTTERY, he witaholdstyom the widow and
the orphan, atd prevents numbers Of poor chl
dren OF an early education, to make them usefu
members OF society.


iaikin falsely charges pr. Purcell with sowing
dscorl III the congrcg gl,ion--this VIC, the t,s.s
tees ofst. Peters Church affirm to be il t.lsc
hood. We offered Dr Purcell 10 take c)arg,
ofour funds, which he refused; and W are ctr,
tain nothing gives you more tronrle tlan yot!
not getting hold of them. The balance Of pes
rent and subscriptions 10 the chtcii, " hri. re.
NAMED in Your hands at the time y"u w,r, re
moved from the Office Of Treasurer, you hGid "
this time You keep all Our former bo4fs anC
church accounts, and thereby the church sus
RI tans a great loss.


The pencil Of an Angelo or Raphael--th,
tongue OF a Cicero Burk, GrAtan, OF Cuir4n
would not be adequate TO describe the perii'l, o
T that man. lie is as dro,s among metal, chat a
mong grain, wolf among sheep, and bad mem
, Der among the children OF God

full articles.headline: TO TILE PUBLIC.
full articles.article:
WE, the trustees Of st. Peters Church in the
Borough OF Wilmington, State OF Delaware, see
ng an appeal to the public by william Larkin,
wherein he charges us, Peter Pierce, Bernard
M'Cann, Bernard MGuigen, and John Durnin,
with unlusty assailing, and most wantonIy SLAM
dering, the said Vim. Larkin's character. He
then proceeds to say he feels it duty he owes
to himself and his friends to rcpel the unauthor-
ICED, base and untonuded charges made by those
calumniators, and expose them to that contempt
they merit. He then comes forward, honest
man like, to exhibit to public view a statement of
the facts connected with the lottery case alluded
to: he requests the public to recolect the pc
riod the Legislature granted the lottery, in 1922,
for raising the sum Of 5000 dollars for the use of
st Peters Church and payment Of debts, over all
expenses; he then states the managers of the
lottery then agreed that one Of them should sign
the tickets, and receive the money, and pay
the pri2es-this was the most Substantial part of
the business, although poor Billy says il was un-
ortunate for him, or, the self-created trustees
would have it, it was unfortunate for the Church
the trustees are a set OF impndent fellows, for
not plying poor Billy's severe loss, and not the
losses of the church; poor Billy goes on to in
form the public he sold the lottery to Thomas
Hope, who commenced to sell the Tickets; and
after the sale of the first and second classes, hon
est Biy tells the public, with the most bare





and note, and payment oidcbts, the full amount
and upwards, say 1905 dollars Ashe treats the
pubIc opinion with the same nsoIence as he has
treated the congregation of St Peters Church,
we now challenge you to come before any three
or more respectable men of the Borough, and we
arc ready to meet any hour you appoint, face to
face, and if YOU can produce one solitary docu-
ment of receipt or settlement for any sum o.
money, even for one dollar, since the commence
ment of the drawing of the lottery until thi
day, we shall acknowledge your assertion to be
true, and ifyeM cannot produce any receipt o
settlement from the trustees of ST. Peter
Church you must be the most abandoned crea
ture upon carth--we challenge you to produce i
in forty-eight hours, or you stand convicted, a
YOU are; so that we shall prevent you from
imposing any longer on the public. Our for
bearance for so long time with you, was from
motives of charity, not wishing to iniure you
character, as we would do, for any man in busi
ness; but you are the same obdurat'
and perverted wretch STILL after all our indul
pence to you. We point out an infamous false
hood on the face of the document you have Sc
before the public, where you say you sold 81.
classes of the lottery to Thomas Hope for 50
dollars each, to be paid by Hope as each clas
was Sold You state that after the lst and Cd class
es were sold, you paid the church the sum Q
1906 dollars in cash and note. You could not pa
uns Of ope thousand dollars, which you state yo

full articles.headline: March /, 1877
full articles.article:
Mr., Billy Laikn why are YOU barking at nc
We never had the change Of an unpleasant word.
+! know Of no cause Of your slan,lerously abusing
me, excepting my refusing you to put my shoul
der, as YOU termed it, to shove yoUr improper
paper, which you called your accompt current,
without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
uftruth. IshoNed it TO Mr. Wales, who is one
of the four law agents employed against you.--
Do you state there is no suit against YOU but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. Mr. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intrudcd yourself in
Ia my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr.. keenan, SAY he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that MIR. keenan, is parish priest in Lancaster;
and that he told you never lived in Lancaster,
so sec that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink. You forget when
you committed your ialsehoods and deiamations
to be published, that your attack on me must
! be founded ON envy and falsehood; as the public
know that ! advertise in this Borough in two
newspapers to let every one in the United
States know who | am, what | am, and where
am, so that YOU are, to make the most of YOU
bad minded man. The principle cause, be
| cyc, of your behaviour, is my sending you bach
pound of spermaceti candles, which wanted
quarter of pound Of the weight. done SO t.
prevent your doing 50 again-you, in an nsolen
manner, told the woman that your weights were
as honest as mine. But this would not do, you
son had to give hera pound of candles, as sh
paid YOU for them This is one ofthe causes G
your savage lying, and vindictiye malice.


]. PURCELL.


February %, 1927 M-4tp'

full articles.headline: Soap and Candle Mandatory.
full articles.article:
THE Subscriber takes this opportunity to in
form the public, that the establishment hereto
fore conducted by James Ray, Esq, together
with the accounts connected with the business
of that establishment from the first of January,
1926, have passed into his hands; and that he
will continue the business in all It's branches, at
the Old Stand, corner of Tatnall and Queen-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House, where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,
Mould and Dipt CANDLES, Fuiier's, Feilow and
Brolun soar, of the best quality.


ENOCH ROBERTS.
N. b. The highest price given for ralow,
Butchers Fat, and Fat Of every description.
Wilmington Nov IS. 1926 8-6m-.

full articles.headline:
TI1E EAMER,

From the New-England Farmer,
LITTER FOR CATTLE.
full articles.article:
Litter is very essential to cattle, when let
into yards, without which yard manure is q
small account, and unless it be in fuH flro-
portion to the cattle in the yard, it is not
thought highly of; but is as half done thing.
Good farmers in England. deem FIJI litter
ing of cattle, when in yards, of such impor-
tance that after reaping with sickes and in
ming their wheat, they cut The stubbl- and
stack it for litter. Besides straw and stub
BILE for litter, they apply to the same use,
fern (brakes) and such other vegetable sub
stances as they can procure; and they buy
straw from common farmers who are not in
the practice of littering. In all countries.
common farmers are indifferent to improve
ments they look not beyond cid habits. and
it is prudent that they venture not on eXten-
sive new projects, without first making ex-
pertinent A full littering is three loads OF
10 or 13,0oolbs. OF straw to each grown
beast.


1t would be more economical however,
to cut the straw with a straw cutter, even
when It is intended for litter. But if cut and
mixed, OF given with other food or roots it
affords wholesome provender for cattle.
The best way, therefore, is to litter your cat
tie with brakes, stubbies, leaves and other
vegetable substances of less value than
straw, and cut and distribute yonr straw for
fodder. Ifpossible feed your cattle under
cover, and provide them at least a shed to
lodge under, and they will require not only
less litter but less food than if fed and lodg,
ed in an open yard. "Many farmers" says
the Domestic Encyclopedia, feed in their
yards in racks, and suppose they gain every
possible advantage from the practice. by the
saving of dung dropped, trampled and wa
tered by the cattle; and though this practice
is certainly preferable to wastetul pasturns
or to feeding in rack Cor from stacks i'll the
fields, vet it ought to be recolleeted that the
manure will be much inferior to that made
and preserved under cover. For there are OBJ
jections against the practice Of yard feeding,
viz: Danger from a vicious beast injurins
another, the irritation arising from then
contentious for food and worrying BY flies,
all of which are avoided BY feeding in stalls
under cover"

full articles.headline:
Imtorta0t lses cftAe ieavca ofthe Crate


1iue
full articles.article:
From experiments made by Sir James
Hall. it has been found that the leaves Of
the grapevine. dried in the shade, make an
excellent and extremely wholesome tea,
though differing in taste and favour from
that commonly used. Besides also being ad
mirably calculated for making Vinegar, the
prunings of the vine, on being bruised and
put into vat or mashng tub, and boiling
water poured over them, in the same way
as is done with malt, will produce liquor OF
a fine vinous quality, which being fer
mented, forms substitute for beer; and
which, on being distilled produces good
spirit Of the nature of brandy.

full articles.headline: TO TEE TUBLIC.
full articles.article:
In the "NVilmingtohian" Of the 18th inst,
a very scurrilous publication appeared over
the signatures OF Peter Pierce, Bernard M
Gu;gen, Bernard Nj Cam and John Durnin,
self STYLED Trustees of the Catholic Church,
in Wilmington, in which my character has
been uniustv assailed, and most wantonly
slanderetl. / feel it a duty owe to myself
aud my friends. to iepel the unauthorized,
base and unfounded charges made by those
calum1lators, and expose them to that con-
tempt they ~ rit; BY exhibiting to the pub
lie a stst. nent of the ftcts connected with
the Lottery case allNdcdto as briefly as prac-
ticAbie, Wlth a comment, from which they
may be eua1letl to form their Judgments.


Il may be recolccted, that on application
q. the Trustees OF st. Peters Church, at
Wilmington, the Legislature ct Delaware,
u 1922, authorized the raising by Lottery,
l3htbc usc If the CEurch, and payment ot
ucb,s, the suin Ct three thotaAi d dollars, (o-
yer and 5alcna all eAPchses) aud in that
law named certain MaueSer, to Superntend
tlr Lottery some in Wilmington and some
III Philadelphia. III conformity with the


rayisloh, Of the Law, tne Managers pro-
CettlcL to discharge tic trust COT tided 20
them At,cr this period the Managers u
nittt!, ~ opinion, that one ot them should
sign the Tickets. and receive and make paw
II. eut If priaes. Unfortunately for me, or,
as thc self-crrAtcd Trustees would have IT,
TOR the Church. was selected tor that pur
pose, the residue ui the NJ lnagers giving me
their bond of indemnity against any loss in
the performance Of that duty.


The Scheme Of this Lottery was sold to
Thomas Hope, Hyokcr, by. and with the
consent Of the Managers, for the sum of
4 three thousand doldrs-to be drawn in Six
classes, payable $500 at the drawing of each
t class Under that arrangement Mr. Hope
| Vent on, ana drew two classes. For those
two classes paid the Church in cash and
Note, and payment OF her debts the full a
mount and upwards, say sixteen hundred
and FIVE dollars and fourteen cents. The
| Third class of this Lottery, was subsequent
4 v under the direction OF Patrick Higgins,
and conducted by him, and many Of the tick
cts IN that class remained unsold. The phi
ues in that class ! was called OH for, aud OBJ
lised to pay; by my signing, ] was pledged
t. reicem them. On Hope falling in his en-
Eagtments the Fourth class was sold to
Z Messls Yates and M'Intyre, The moucy
received for the class drawn by them, ac-
cording to contract, was applied (and pald)
Is the deficiency Of the Sd class, conducted
by Patrick Higgins. All of these facts, |
remain ready and willing to make appear ii
defence of the suit tcn erAi'mg'y shoten Gt
but 72hich has never Uetn commenced, altho'
80 boiiy ASSERTED.


As ;athc etnlitaietian 81 nv services, bv
thps, "!tuSttesn, il is .rLtY idieulous. /
k!n.. Of NJ powers they possess to grant to
NO. .Ng Ep;er"s art from 4 higher and
r"rc r@sp,c ct,aic source lhnsc men need
enlylpy aen. themselves, and they viii pro-
habty receive i, Of 'ht kind in legal way
not con t3rtable TO thpm. a pacC Ut thu. fWnds
of t!lr GGurch, w'llI. 10 doubt, be very con
Ncatent to uUr "tIentlemcn Trustees" but
#hcA Il is hoped thc good sense Of the con-
Grrgation will prevent them from handling;
aha very unfortunate indeed would 1t he for
the Church, to confide her concerns in such
hanas, 7ab2 have not sufficient discretion to
conduct their own affairs. | would observe,
that ~ dissatisfaction would have arose, but
tor two ,llsorganiling members, one OF whom
undertook to perform part III the Lottery,
which his incapaCity untitled him for, where
by he was abandoned; and he did not reap
50 ricl harvest as his fancy led him to ex-
pect.


would further remark, that the second,
is certain nondescript, d pettifogging Doc
tor, who is every thing by turns and nothing
long, affecting to be a Catholic, and who,


Hogan ike, would destroy the Church. He
has been sowing discord and dissention a
mong the members since he came to WI
r mington. From whence he came, or who he
is, God only knows. 1t has been said he
, formerly resided in Lancaster, hut for what
he left Lancaster, whether by day or night
: for the safety Of his c0rcuse, or by the advice
t Of t7rclve honr@ yeomen, l know not.
Z | am attached to the Catholic church
2 which affords me satisfaction; and | feel q
n pride in promoting the interests of the
: Church; and do hope the congregation vii
\ be on their guard against the tricks attempt
ed to be practised on them by such an un-
principled renegade.


) feel consciousness of the correctness
:, of the course pursued by me in regard to tht
= Church, and that it has not only been just
. . and honuurable, but that instead of gain
= have sustained a toss, by my attention tt
e her concerns, which | can make appear sa
o tisfactorly to any unprecedented mind.
